comments:
Eclipse 3.3 I20060822-1200, IBM Java 5.0SR2, WinXP SP2. Steps to reproduce

* start fresh workspace and paste the code below there

package t;
import java.util.Stack;
public class T {
  void t() {
    final class C {
    }
    final Stack<C> stack = new 
//                             ^ hit Ctrl-Space here
	}
}

* use content assist to finish "... new Stack<C>();" statement
* move cursor back to indicated location and activate contect assists again


Problem: "Problem During Content Assist" dialog pops up and NullPointerException is written to .log

Cannot reproduce using plain Eclipse SDK and the Java editor with either Sun or IBM 5.0 VM.

Please provide more details.

Strange, this is 100% reproducable for me with fresh workspace and all default settings. Both with SUN and IBM VMs. Will retest with today's I-build when it becomes available.

I spent some time debugging JavaTypeCompletionProposalComputer.computeCompletionProposals and here is what I've found

* there are three proposed types at the indicated location in the order
  [C, T - t, Stack<C> - java.util]

* #getJavaElement() for proposed type C returns null for some reason

* If content assist history for java.util.Stack is not empty, typeProposal.getJavaElement().getFullyQualifiedName() fails with NPE for proposal C


Another annoying thing is when code assist does work, it actually inserts "Stack<T>" even though drop-down offers "Stack<C> - java.util". Not sure if this is related.

Hope this helps.
Do you use plain Eclipse SDK?

>Do you use plain Eclipse SDK?
I mean did you do this with just Eclipse SDK and no additional plug-ins?
Yes, plain eclipse I20060822-1200 without any additional plugins. Just recreated my eclipse install to be sure. Also tried with today's I20060829-0800 and got to same problem.
Can you check whether the JRE in your workspace has source attached or not?
It does not matter, the problem occurs with or without JRE source attached. Sametime me (igorf at ca ibm com) if you want to access my system.

OK, I can now reproduce too - no idea why it wasn't possible before.

Tom, the code on line 90 does not protect against 'null' (which is bad) but the more intersting question is whether the proposal is wrong in the first place, see also last part of comment 2.
Fixed the NPE. The wrong parameterization mentioned in comment 2 seems to be  bug in jdt.core. I have filed bug 156845 to track this.
